Award.AwardTitle: PREEVENTS: Workshop on Integrated Framework for Modeling and Prediction of Extreme Events; College Park, Maryland; Summer 2016
Award.AbstractNarration:
PREEVENTS: Workshop on Uncertainty Quantification in Forecasting Extreme Space Weather

The project is to organize and provide travel support for a three-day workshop that targets the understanding of extreme events in space weather. The extreme nature of events arises when many conditions reinforce disturbances, such as geospace storms and substorms. The identification and characterization of these conditions are essential to uncertainty quantification and to improvements in modeling and prediction. The workshop will bring together experts in geospace modeling and simulation to explore common issues in the modeling and prediction of space weather using data-driven and first-principles approaches. A primary objective will be the identification of what is needed for the development of an integrated framework for uncertainty quantification that leverages advances in the two approaches to accelerate research to improve space weather forecasting. This is an important next step that will most likely lead to innovative and synergistic approaches to developing future capabilities. An important output of the workshop will be a comprehensive report on the current state of, and future outlook for, modeling and prediction of extreme space weather events and the associated natural hazards. The workshop provides a rare and valuable opportunity to broaden the education of postdocs, graduate and undergraduate students and enable networking. The workshop will contribute to the development of a multi-disciplinary community for disaster science, which is critical to accelerate the development of a framework for extreme event prediction and mitigation.

The understanding of the statistics of rare events and their variability is critical to uncertainty quantification in space weather forecasting, and the paucity of data of extreme events requires development of new techniques. The nonlinear coupling among the different multiphysical processes underlying extreme events, and the incomplete knowledge of the underlying processes themselves, are among the main sources of uncertainty in first principles models. An essential step to improving forecasts of extreme space weather is uncertainty quantification, which is inherently interdisciplinary, requiring a comprehensive effort that brings together disciplinary researchers, computational scientists, modelers, and statisticians. The workshop provides a forum for identifying and exploring important synergisms in forecasting extreme events in space weather and its outcomes can impact extreme events forecasting in general.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Extreme events in the earth system lead to natural hazards, such as space storms, earthquakes, tornadoes and floods. Such hazards can have devastating impacts on humans and our society, and developing the capability to predict them is an important societal need.   With the ever growing technological infrastructure, space weather and its impacts play an increasingly important role in our society. Recognizing the importance  of extreme events, from the research perspective as well as societal needs, a workshop on “Modeling and Prediction of Extreme Space Weather Events” was organized at the University of Maryland, College Park, Maryland during 22-24 August 2018. The workshop was sponsored by the NSF PREEVENTS and Geospace Programs and focused on multidisciplinary research.  The participants represented  academic institutions, national laboratories, federal centers and commercial organizations, from the USA and abroad.  

The major goal of the workshop was to explore the development of a framework for the modeling and prediction of extreme events, based on the underlying physical processes and the inherent features obtained from data. Considering the common characteristics of extreme events on the earth and in geospace,  an interdisciplinary approach for developing a common framework is an important step in developing a better understanding.  The workshop was viewed as an essential first step toward this goal to identify the common features extreme events in different components of the earth system, to assess the roles of the physical processes and to develop ways to harness the extensive data.   

The research in extreme events was reviewed from the two perspectives common to the geoscience disciplines, viz. the first-principles and data-driven approaches. Although the first-principles approaches have different underlying principles for different phenomena, the common aspects were noted as potential directions for future efforts. For example, the large scale numerical models of terrestrial and space weather are based on similar type of equations, and developments in addressing the leading issues in one area are very likely to have important implications to the other.  The recognition that the data-driven approaches were widely used in the modeling and prediction of extreme events in many disciplines underscore the need to assess the current capabilities. The discussions of the recent advances in different disciplines highlighted the need to integrate the first-principle approach based on physical processes and the data-driven approach harnessing the data revolution, for research and for meeting societal needs.

A brief summary of the workshop has been published as a meeting report (Sharma, A. S., E. E. Kalnay, and M. Bonadonna (2017), Predictive capability for extreme space weather events, Eos, 98, https://doi.org/10.1029/2017EO071721. Published on 26 April 2017).
